Here you can find all the components available in the registry.
A collection of accessible components built with Greta UI.

import { GITHUB_REPO_URL } from "@/data/env" Just like Greta UI, this is not a component library. Instead it is a collection of components that you can use to build your own component library. These components are designed to be accessible and customizable, so you can easily integrate them into your projects. Each component in this library is built to solve specific problems that most developers face while building web applications (such as asynchronous actions, form validation, etc.). If there are any components that you would like to see added to this library, please feel free to open an issue on the GitHub repository.
A button that performs an action when clicked and optionally asks for user confirmation.

import CodePreview from "@/components/markdown/code-preview/code-preview.astro"
import Installation from "@/components/markdown/installation-tabs/installation-tabs.astro"
import ToastProvider from "@/components/markdown/toast-provider.astro"

<CodePreview demo="action-button/basic" />

## Installation

<Installation registryItem="action-button" />

## Usage

```tsx
import { ActionButton } from "@/components/ui/action-button"
```

```tsx
import { updateSettings } from "@/actions/settings"

const settings = { name: "Kyle" }

<ActionButton
  action={updateSettings.bind(null, settings)}
  requireAreYouSure
>
  Save Settings
</ActionButton>
```

### Default

<CodePreview demo="action-button/default" />

### With Error

A multi-select input that emulates the Shadcn Select component as closely as possible.

import CodePreview from "@/components/markdown/code-preview/code-preview.astro"
import Installation from "@/components/markdown/installation-tabs/installation-tabs.astro"
import ToastProvider from "@/components/markdown/toast-provider.astro"

<CodePreview demo="multi-select/basic" />

## Installation

<Installation registryItem="multi-select" />

## Usage

```tsx
import {
  MultiSelect,
  MultiSelectContent,
  MultiSelectGroup,
  MultiSelectItem,
  MultiSelectTrigger,
  MultiSelectValue,
} from "@/components/ui/multi-select"
```

```tsx
<MultiSelect>
  <MultiSelectTrigger className="w-full max-w-[400px]">
    <MultiSelectValue placeholder="Select frameworks..." />
  </MultiSelectTrigger>
  <MultiSelectContent>
    <MultiSelectGroup>
      <MultiSelectItem value="next.js">Next.js</MultiSelectItem>
      <MultiSelectItem value="sveltekit">SvelteKit</MultiSelectItem>
      <MultiSelectItem value="astro">Astro</MultiSelectItem>
      <MultiSelectItem value="vue">Vue.js</MultiSelectItem>
    </MultiSelectGroup>
  </MultiSelectContent>
</MultiSelect>
```

### Overflow Behavior

<CodePreview demo="multi-select/overflow-behavior" />

Request a component you think should be added.

import { Steps } from "@astrojs/starlight/components"

<Steps>

1. **Check Existing Components**

   Review the [components list](/components) and the [GitHub discussions tab](https://github.com/bhavya-quest/greta-ui/discussions/categories/component-request) to see if the component is already implemented or requested.

2. **Open a Discussion**

   Go to the GitHub repository and [start a new discussion](https://github.com/bhavya-quest/greta-ui/discussions/new?category=component-request).

3. **Describe the Component**

   Provide a clear description, use cases, and any references or examples. The more detailed a request is, the easier it is for maintainers to understand and implement.

</Steps>
Thanks for your interest in contributing to Greta UI.

import { FileTree, Steps } from "@astrojs/starlight/components"

Please take a moment to review this document before submitting your first pull request. We also strongly recommend that you check for open issues and pull requests to see if someone else is working on something similar.

## About this repository

This repository is an Astro Starlight project.

- We use `npm` for development.
- We use `prettier` for code formatting (which is automatically run on commit).

## Structure

This repository is structured as follows:

<FileTree>

- src
  - assets/
  - components/
  - content/docs
    - components/
    - getting-started/
    - contributing/
  - registry/greta
    - examples/
    - items/

</FileTree>

- `src/assets`: Any logos/images for the documentation site.
- `src/components`: Components used to create the documentation site.
- `src/content/docs/components`: Individual documentation pages for each component.
- `src/content/getting-started`: One-off guides for the getting started section of the documentation.
- `src/content/docs/contributing`: Documentation for contributing to the registry.
- `src/registry/greta/examples`: Example files used for rendering in the documentation pages for each component.
- `src/registry/greta/items`: The implementation of the component that will be installed in the user's project.

## Development

<Steps>

1. **[Fork the repository](https://github.com/bhavya-quest/greta-ui/fork)**
2. **Clone on your local machine**

   ```bash
   git clone git@github.com:bhavya-quest/greta-ui.git
   ```

3. **Navigate to project directory**

   ```bash
   cd greta-ui
   ```

4. **Create a new Branch**

   ```bash
   git checkout -b my-new-branch
   ```

5. **Install dependencies**

   ```bash
   npm i
   ```

6. **Copy `.env.example` to `.env`**

   ```bash
   cp .env.example .env
   ```

7. **Run the development server**

   ```bash
   npm run dev
   ```

</Steps>

## Building the registry locally

To test that your registry builds correctly, you can run the following command:

```bash
npm registry:build
```

Then try installing any component from the registry in a new project using the `shadcn add` command:

```bash
npx shadcn@latest add http://localhost:4321/r/<component-name>.json
```
Request a feature you think should be implemented.

import { Steps } from "@astrojs/starlight/components"

<Steps>

1. **Search Existing Issues**

   Review the [GitHub issues](https://github.com/bhavya-quest/greta-ui/issues?q=is%3Aissue%20state%3Aopen%20label%3Aenhancement) to see if the feature has already been requested.

2. **Open a Issue**

   Go to the GitHub repository and [open a new issue](https://github.com/bhavya-quest/greta-ui/issues) using the `Feature Request` template.

3. **Describe the Feature**

   Explain the motivation, expected behavior, and possible alternatives. The more detailed a request is, the easier it is for maintainers to understand and implement.

</Steps>

_This is not for requesting new components. For that, please see [Component Request](/contributing/component-request)._

How to install Greta UI components in your project.

import CliCommandCode from "@/components/markdown/cli-command-code/cli-command-code.astro"
import { SERVER_URL } from "@/data/env"

It doesn't matter what framework or package manager you are using. Installing Greta UI components is as simple as running the `shadcn add @greta/<component>` command and replacing `<component>` with the name of the component you want to install.

The entire install process is handled by the `shadcn` CLI tool and works identically to how you would install any other Greta UI component.

## Example

<CliCommandCode action="run" command="shadcn@latest add @greta/action-button" />

_If that doesn't work you can use the full URL to the component's JSON file instead._

<CliCommandCode
  action="run"
  command={`shadcn@latest add ${SERVER_URL}/r/action-button.json`}
/>
WDS Shadcn Registry is a collection of accessible components built for use with Shadcn.

import { GITHUB_REPO_URL } from "@/data/env" Just like Shadcn, this is not a component library. Instead it is a collection of components that you can use to build your own component library. These components are designed to be accessible and customizable, so you can easily integrate them into your projects. Each component in this library is built to solve specific problems that most developers face while building web applications (such as asynchronous actions, form validation, etc.). If there are any components that you would like to see added to this library, please feel free to open an issue on the GitHub repository.
